title: How to Clean a Patio

steps.headline: Declutter your patio.
steps.description: Remove any items that doesn't belong there or broken.

steps.headline: Sweep or rinse the entire patio so that all dirt, debris and leaves are removed.
Remove weeds.
steps.description: Weeds do not look attractive on a patio, remove the biggest weeds and use a simple kitchen knife to easily remove the leftover or smallest weeds between the patio tiles. You can spray weed killers or pour salt between the patio tiles to kill them for good.

steps.headline: Make a solution of one cup bleach and pour into a bucket water.
steps.description: When the patio is really dirty use undiluted bleach. If the patio is regularly  cleaned use brown soap.

steps.headline: Scrub the entire patio vigorously with a stiff brush.
steps.description: While using chlorine bleach be careful when you are scrubbing near grass or plants, the bleach can kill them. If you are using undiluted bleach pour it on the patio and let it rest for a couple of minutes or hours (depending on how dirty the patio is) and come back and start scrubbing. If you use brown soap, just pour some soap over the patio add water and start scrubbing.

steps.headline: Rinse the patio carefully or if you used undiluted bleach let it rest for a night and rinse the next morning.
Make a mixture of one cup of brown soap or soda crystals in a bucket of water and pour it over the stone patio.
steps.description: Before you use any soap or detergent make sure that it's appropriate for the patio tiles, some tiles need a special cleaner.

steps.headline: Scrub the patio vigorously with a stiff brush.
Let it rest for a couple of minutes.
steps.description: When preferred you can also spray white vinegar between the cracks of the tiles to remove and kill the weeds.

steps.headline: Rinse the patio carefully.
steps.description: Be careful that the soapy water does end up on your lawn or flower beds as this can kill them!

text: Preparation Declutter your patio. Remove any items that doesn't belong there or broken. Sweep or rinse the entire patio so that all dirt, debris and leaves are removed.  Remove weeds. Weeds do not look attractive on a patio, remove the biggest weeds and use a simple kitchen knife to easily remove the leftover or smallest weeds between the patio tiles. You can spray weed killers or pour salt between the patio tiles to kill them for good. Concrete patio Make a solution of one cup bleach and pour into a bucket water. When the patio is really dirty use undiluted bleach. If the patio is regularly  cleaned use brown soap. Scrub the entire patio vigorously with a stiff brush. While using chlorine bleach be careful when you are scrubbing near grass or plants, the bleach can kill them. If you are using undiluted bleach pour it on the patio and let it rest for a couple of minutes or hours (depending on how dirty the patio is) and come back and start scrubbing. If you use brown soap, just pour some soap over the patio add water and start scrubbing. Rinse the patio carefully or if you used undiluted bleach let it rest for a night and rinse the next morning.  Stone patio Make a mixture of one cup of brown soap or soda crystals in a bucket of water and pour it over the stone patio. Before you use any soap or detergent make sure that it's appropriate for the patio tiles, some tiles need a special cleaner. Scrub the patio vigorously with a stiff brush.  Let it rest for a couple of minutes. When preferred you can also spray white vinegar between the cracks of the tiles to remove and kill the weeds. Rinse the patio carefully. Be careful that the soapy water does end up on your lawn or flower beds as this can kill them!
sentences: Preparation Declutter your patio.
Remove any items that doesn't belong there or broken.
Sweep or rinse the entire patio so that all dirt, debris and leaves are removed.
Remove weeds.
Weeds do not look attractive on a patio, remove the biggest weeds and use a simple kitchen knife to easily remove the leftover or smallest weeds between the patio tiles.
You can spray weed killers or pour salt between the patio tiles to kill them for good.
Concrete patio Make a solution of one cup bleach and pour into a bucket water.
When the patio is really dirty use undiluted bleach.
If the patio is regularly  cleaned use brown soap.
Scrub the entire patio vigorously with a stiff brush.
While using chlorine bleach be careful when you are scrubbing near grass or plants, the bleach can kill them.
If you are using undiluted bleach pour it on the patio and let it rest for a couple of minutes or hours (depending on how dirty the patio is) and come back and start scrubbing.
If you use brown soap, just pour some soap over the patio add water and start scrubbing.
Rinse the patio carefully or if you used undiluted bleach let it rest for a night and rinse the next morning.
Stone patio Make a mixture of one cup of brown soap or soda crystals in a bucket of water and pour it over the stone patio.
Before you use any soap or detergent make sure that it's appropriate for the patio tiles, some tiles need a special cleaner.
Scrub the patio vigorously with a stiff brush.
Let it rest for a couple of minutes.
When preferred you can also spray white vinegar between the cracks of the tiles to remove and kill the weeds.
Rinse the patio carefully.
Be careful that the soapy water does end up on your lawn or flower beds as this can kill them!
